title: 110_hr7104
content: The "National Commission on Financial Collapse and Recovery Act of 2008" establishes the National Commission on the Financial Collapse and Recovery as an establishment in the legislative branch with duties outlined. The Commission's duties include examining the causes of the 2008 financial collapse, collecting evidence from relevant government agencies, accounting for the failures, and making recommendations for preventive measures. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders, with a limit of 5 members from the same political party. Appointees cannot be government officials and should be prominent US citizens. The Commission members must be prominent US citizens with expertise in various professions and no conflicts of interest. They should be appointed within 30 days of the enactment of the Act and the Chairman will be elected by the members. The Commission will start operations promptly after the members are appointed. After its initial meeting, the Commission will meet as called by the chairman or a majority of its members. A quorum of six members is required for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission will meet as called by the chairman or a majority of its members, with a quorum of six members required for meetings. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission, subcommittees, or members can hold hearings, take testimony, and issue subpoenas to gather evidence for carrying out the Act. Subpoenas may be issued as needed. Subpoenas under this subsection can be issued by the agreement of the chairman and vice chairman or by the affirmative vote of 6 Commission members. Subpoenas may be signed by the chairman or designated member and served by a designated person. Enforcement can be pursued in cases of contumacy. In cases of contumacy or failure to obey a subpoena, the United States district court can issue an order for the person to testify or produce evidence. Failure to comply may result in contempt of court. Additional enforcement measures can be taken for witness non-compliance. The Commission can certify witness failures to the US attorney for grand jury action under the same authority as specified in the Revised Statutes of the United States. Additionally, the Commission is authorized to enter into contracts as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act by requesting data directly from various government entities as authorized by law. The Commission can obtain information from federal agencies as authorized by law. Members of the Commission and its staff must handle information in accordance with applicable laws. The General Services Administration provides administrative support to the Commission, and other federal agencies may offer additional services and support. The Commission can accept gifts and use postal services like other federal agencies. The Commission members may receive compensation not exceeding the daily rate of pay for level IV positions and travel expenses as per federal regulations. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for preventive measures. The Commission and all authorities under the Act will terminate 60 days after the report submission, during which they may conclude activities and provide testimony to Congress. SEC. 9. FUNDING. $2,000,000 appropriated from Treasury for Commission activities under this Act. Additional funding authorized as necessary.
